MoS2 has received a lot of attention as a carrier for single-atom catalysts owing to its stable layered structure and outstanding electrical transport characteristics. We developed a model that represents the Pt@MoS2 SACs in this study on anatomical coordination environment with doping elements consisting of C, B, N, and P. It was investigated how catalytic and electrical properties interact with HER activity.The outcomes shown that C, B, N, and P significantly modified the electronic structure of the catalyst surface and enhanced catalytic activity when doped into the loaded Pt single atom of MoS2. The best effects were seen with B and C doping, with free energies reaching -0.004 and -0.071 eV, respectively. The universality of the doping sites made it simpler to produce in experiments, because C doping in other positions still had fantastic catalytic activity. The project is anticipated to offer a theoretical framework for further exploration of MoS2 in the catalytic arena and the investigation of analogous structured catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MoS2 Single-atom catalysts Element doping First-principles Hydrogen evolution reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Under the goal of "carbon peak and carbon neutrality", exploring clean energy has become one of the important aspects for future development. Electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction(HER) has attracted significant attention from researchers and engineers [1,2]. High-quality electrocatalysts should have several features: 1. Low-cost and green preparation processes to reduce dependence on precious metals; 2. High intrinsic activity and rich active sites; 3. Excellent interfacial charge transfer ability; 4. Stable catalytic performance at industrial current densities. Subsequently, developing HER electrocatalysts that balance cost, environmental friendliness, and high-efficiency selectivity is an important measure to meet the challenges of future energy era [3]. The utilization of two-dimensional (2D) materials has expanded to various fields due to their enhanced quantum confinement. Compared to three-dimensional (3D) semiconductor materials, 2D material catalysts have significantly higher specific surface areas and pronounced carrier mobility anisotropy, making them more competitive and providing sufficient adsorption sites [4,5]. MoS2 is a commonly used material for electrocatalysts, as the stable 2D material formed by the S-Mo-S atomic layer has a high specific surface area and robustness, providing strong support for hydrogen acquisition [6]. MoS2 has three different phase structures, including 1T, 2H, and 3R. Among them, 2H-MoS2 is the most common in nature, but its inert basal plane and low conductivity limit its energy conversion efficiency. 1T-MoS2 is a structure that appears on the basis of 2H-MoS2 with the in-plane sliding of S atoms, and it has been found to exhibit excellent conductivity [7,8]. Manufacturing single-atom catalysts(SACs) has become an essential step in improving the high selectivity and catalytic activity of 2H-MoS2 electrocatalysts for HER. Due to its 100% surface utilization and ideal selectivity, SACs have emerged as a hot topic in catalysis research [9,10]. Platinum and platinum derivatives are considered to be the best catalysts for water splitting to produce hydrogen [11,12]. Platinum and platinum derivatives are considered as the best catalysts for cracking water to produce hydrogen, and the interaction between platinum and the catalyst carrier has also attracted wide interest [13,14]. Recently, Yongwen Tan's team [15] designed an electrocatalyst material of single-atom(SA) loaded porous molybdenum disulfide. The Ru/np-MoS2 electrocatalyst was constructed by combining CVD method with spontaneous oxidation–reduction doping method. The synergistic effect between Ru SA and the carrier significantly increased the electron density of S vacancies in porous MoS2, improving the HER activity. At a current density of 10 mA∙cm−2, the overpotential of the catalyst was 30 mV, and it had a long catalytic life. Applying tension may enhance the proton transfer process at the catalyst's surface further, which is beneficial for the coupling of HH and the dissociation of H2O. On top of that, it was discovered that Pt SACs may display a more advantageous surface plasmon resonance impact of precious metal-carrier on HER reactions, which can result in an additional catalytic electron contribution [16]. Rongming Wang [17] synthesized single-dispersed and single-crystal platinum nanoparticles (∼3 nm) decorated on 2H-MoS2 nanosheets using a universal wet chemical method. By manipulating the d-band center of the Pt nanoparticles surface, adjacent S atoms have the minimum hydrogen adsorption free energy. Regardlessiy, there is currently a lack of more coupling methods to regulate SACs, and the combined use of multiple modification methods may achieve more outstanding reaction results. Further exploration is needed in this regard. Currently, the design of coordination environment for 2H-MoS2 to enhance its catalytic performance is an important scientific issue [18,19]. Surface design of catalysts through element doping can effectively improve the activity of interface charges, providing more driving force for HER initiation. In particularly, adjusting the electronic structure and chemical properties of MoS2 through doping with metal or non-metal elements can enhance its catalytic activity and stability [20,21]. Jin Wang et al. doped C to form 2H/1T, 2H/1T, and 1T/1T' non-phase interfaces of MoS2. During the deposition process, C doping induced a phase transition from 2H to 1T or 1T', improving the charge transfer ability [22]. This indicates that the introduction of heteroatoms into molybdenum disulfide can effectively improve the inert basal plane of the catalyst and synergistically adjust the surface electron flow. Notwithstanding, there is still a lack of comprehensive experimental and theoretical guidance, which is necessary for the design of efficient molybdenum disulfide-based electrocatalysts. This work employed the density functional theory (DFT) calculation method to investigate the changes in HER activity of Pt SACs on 2H-MoS2 (hereafter abbreviated as MoS2) doped with heteroatoms A (A = C, B, N, P). By exploring the Pt SA loading position, H adsorption site, reaction free energy, and electronic properties, we elucidate the structure-activity relationship of HER, providing a research basis for the precise coordination environment regulation of catalysts. 2 Calculation method In this study, electronic property calculations were performed using the Castep module of the Materials Studio quantum computing software package. MoS2 was surface reconstructed along the (001) crystal plane. The electron correlation energy was considered using the generalized gradient approximation functional (GGA-PBE) [23]. The strong Coulomb exchange interaction between electrons in the transition metal d-level was also considered. The electronic properties were calculated using the ultrasoft pseudopotential (OTFG) method, and the spin-orbit coupling effect (SOC) and Tkatchenko-Scheffler (TS) dispersion correction were used to accurately describe the semiconductor electronic structure [24]. The convergence test was performed, and the cutoff energy value was set to 570 eV. The K-point grid in the Brillouin zone was selected as 7 × 7 × 1 for band structure, differential charge density, and adsorption energy calculations. For the density of states and charge density calculations, the K-point grid was selected as 12 × 12 × 1 to obtain more accurate performance trends [25]. The thickness of the Z-direction vacuum layer was set to 18 Å to avoid interaction between layers. The molecular dynamics calculations were performed using the Dmol3 module, and the canonical ensemble (NVT) was used for testing. The total step length was set to 2.5 Ps with 2500 iterations. Geometric structure optimization was stopped when the force and energy standards reached 0.01 eV∙Å−1 and 10−6 eV, respectively, and the maximum displacement was 0.01 Å to ensure that the established model was closer to the actual crystal structure. Relevant property calculations are shown in the supporting information. 3 Results and analysis Fig. 1 shows the structural models of the designed MoS2 electrocatalysts. This includes the original MoS2, Pt@MoS2, and Pt@MoS2 doped non-metallic dopant elements, namely C, B, N, and P. The models are labeled as Pt@MoS2(C), Pt@MoS2(B), Pt@MoS2(N), and Pt@MoS2(P), and will be referred to as such in the following text. As can be seen from Fig. 1, whether it is Pt SA loaded, or anchored after C, S, N, and P replace S atoms of MoS2, the bond lengths change very little, indicating that the structure has not changed and still maintains its characteristic structure. The formation energy and binding energy in Table 1 also confirm the structural stability of the catalysts [26]. It is still an excellent steady-state structure for two-dimensional materials like MoS2, despite the fact the binding energy and formation energy of the catalysts marginally drop after non-metallic doping. Molecular dynamics simulations were performed on the Pt@MoS2(C) structure (Fig. 2 (a)), and the energy converged near −22,182.28 eV with a small energy oscillation zone, indicating that the bond length, bond angle, and configuration structure did not change significantly. This confirms the excellent stability of the designed catalyst structure. Analogously, this study calculated the electronic properties of Pt@MoS2, Pt@MoS2(C), Pt@MoS2(B), Pt@MoS2(N), and Pt@MoS2(P). By comparing the effective mass and work function (Fig. 2 (b), Fig.S1), it was found that Pt@MoS2 had the lowest electron and hole effective masses, indicating that this structure had a higher charge transfer rate. Nevertheless, it was obvious from the work function and vacuum energy level that this structure had a considerable propensity to bind electrons, thereby rendering it demanding for electron transfer in reactions involving H + reduction. On the other hand, Pt@MoS2(B) had the lowest work function, and the electron and hole effective masses were relatively low. Additionally, Pt@MoS2(C) had a large difference between the electron and hole effective masses, which were 2.128 and 4.575 m0, respectively. In other words, the transmission rates of electrons and holes were different, reducing the likelihood of recombination and laying the groundwork for the reaction to proceed [27]. Subsequently, we investigated the adsorption position of Pt SA on MoS2, considering four possible adsorption sites: S-top, Mo-top, bridge, and edge. The adsorption energies of Pt SA on the five catalyst structures are shown in Table 1. It can be observed that the adsorption energy on the bridge site is the lowest, indicating th0at Pt is more likely to anchor on the bridge site and form an A-Pt-S bridge structure, which can more effectively achieve the directional movement of surface charges [28]. The hydrogen evolution Gibbs free energy (ΔG H*) can measure the ability of H to adsorb and decorb on the catalyst surface. According to the "Sabatier principle", if the adsorption energy of the intermediate is too strong or too weak, it will lead to an increase or decrease in the bonding effect of the outer electrons, which is not conducive to the formation of perfect electronic interaction and directional transmission of the adsorbate on the catalyst surface [29]. Next, ΔG H* calculations were performed at five different sites on each catalyst structure, and the adsorption site locations are shown in Fig. 3 (a). Site 2 is a doped heteroatom site that does not exist for Pt@MoS2 since Pt@MoS2 is not doping. The results of ΔG H* at each site are shown in Fig. 3 (b), and the ΔG H* of each catalyst at Site 1, i.e. on the Pt SA, is closest to 0. This indicates that Pt becomes the active site for the reaction after being loaded on the catalyst. The ΔG H* values of Pt@MoS2(C) and Pt@MoS2(B) were −0.071 and −0.004 eV, respectively, which were even better than the well-known value of Pt (−0.08 eV) and close to the ideal value of 0 eV (Fig. 4 (a)) [30–32]. We hypothesize that Pt SA, as noble metals, can generate localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effects, thereby decreasing the system's work function and obtaining outstanding HER activity. This is combined with the feature of the system's work function dropping afterwards Pt loading. Because of the LSPR process that occurs when noble metal SAs attached to semiconductor photocatalyst surfaces are excited by light, non-uniform magnetic fields, high-energy charge carriers, and photothermal effects ensue. This improves incident light absorption and scattering, raises electromagnetic intensity close to the catalyst, efficiently manages the surface electronic state, and may encourage an increase in active sites and a decline in reaction rate [33]. Additionally, the intrinsic rate of electrons in HER was measured by calculating the theoretical exchange current density i 0 at the equilibrium potential. The peak on the volcano curve represents the catalyst with the highest HER activity, i.e. the fastest HER reaction rate. From Fig. 4 (b), it can be seen that all five catalysts appeared near the peak of the volcano curve, indicating that they all have high HER activity. Consequently, these five catalysts are expected to become efficient HER catalysts with broad application prospects in fields such as water splitting. In the HER of the catalyst, the electronic orbital and energy level structure involved in the reaction process play a crucial role in the reaction activity. In order to better reveal the contribution of the orbitals in the reaction process, we calculated the partial density of states (PDOS) of the catalysts in the initial state and after HER, as well as the change in d-band center, as shown in Fig. 5 , Fig.S2, and Table 2 . Overall, the S-2p, Mo-4d, and Pt-5d orbitals provide the main contribution to the valence band, while the Mo-4d and S-2p orbitals provide the main contribution to the conduction band. This suggests that molybdenum disulfide is a highly effective electrocatalytic substance. Simultaneously, it was discovered that there is a massive orbital crossing between the outer orbitals of S, Mo, and Pt. This verifies that Pt SA can be securely anchored on the surface of MoS2 and also suggests that Pt SA has a substantial connection to the carrier [34]. The antibonding energy band on the catalyst surface is used to adsorb reactant molecules, and the degree of electron filling of the reactant molecules on the antibonding energy band determines the strength of their interaction with the catalyst surface. If the antibonding energy band is filled with too many electrons, the reactant molecules will experience strong repulsion and the reaction will be difficult to proceed. Conversely, if the antibonding energy band is filled with too few electrons, the reactant molecules will experience insufficient detachment, and the reaction rate will also decrease [35]. When the d-band center of the catalyst is far from the Fermi level, it indicates that the d-electron energy level on the catalyst surface is far from the Fermi level, and the reactants need to overcome a larger energy barrier to interact with the catalyst surface, resulting in a lower reaction rate. Equally, in this situation, the adsorption strength of the catalyst surface for reactants and products will also decrease, leading to a decrease in reaction selectivity [36], such as Pt@MoS2 and Pt@MoS2(N). Consequently, the d-band center far from the Fermi level is generally considered to be an unfavorable electronic state, which cannot provide effective reaction electrons for the reduction of hydrogen. Subsequently, although it is simple to speed up the reaction process by electron contribution and reduce the electron filling of the antibonding energy band when the d-band center is remarkably close to the Fermi level, the ability to combine with adsorbate active H (H*) is also enhanced, which decreases the production quantity of H2. In Pt@MoS2(C), the d-band centers of Mo and Pt SA shift upward and approach the Fermi level, reducing the electron filling of the antibonding energy band and promoting the adsorption of H + on Pt SA. In Pt@MoS2(B), it remains around 0.5 eV before and after the reaction, balancing the electron flow before and after the reaction, which also contributes positively to HER. Overall, the research shows that the doping of heteroatoms effectively improves the surface electronic properties of MoS2 and enhances the freedom of HER. Pt@MoS2(C) and Pt@MoS2(B) are the best-regulated structures. Fig. 6 and Fig.S3 show the schematic diagrams of the difference in charge density before and after HER for Pt@MoS2, Pt@MoS2(C), Pt@MoS2(B), Pt@MoS2(N), and Pt@MoS2(P), respectively. The analysis of bond lengths and Mulliken charges of the atoms is presented in Table 3 . Compared to Pt@MoS2, the charge transfer of the catalysts was enhanced after doping with heteroatoms, and the electron density near the Pt SA was higher, effectively adjusting the charge distribution on the catalyst surface. Additionally, the charge distribution of Pt@MoS2(B) was darker, and the distribution area was contracted. The Pt-S bond layout decreased from −0.04e in the original structure (Pt@MoS2) to −0.16e, and the Mo-S bond layout decreased from 0.40e to 0.28e. The electrons formed an attractive electron flow structure as they moved in the direction of the B atom, increasing the degree of charge separation and the carriers' potential for migration during the catalytic reaction. For Pt@MoS2(C), Pt@MoS2(N), and Pt@MoS2(P), the electron flow towards A was stronger, which also improved the catalytic ability. At this point, the Pt-C bond lost more electrons compared to other bonds, resulting in a better improvement effect on HER. This is consistent with the description of the density of states and free energy. In the above discussion, we found that doping with heteroatoms can effectively adjust the electronic environment of the catalyst surface, and the HER performance is optimal when C and B are doped. Nevertheless, there is a question whether it is feasible to prepare such precisely doped samples in experiments. What if the doping heteroatoms are not located near the loaded Pt SAs? Here, we further discuss the changes in catalytic performance when C and B are doped at other positions, and provide a feasible solution for experimental design. The doping positions are shown in Fig. 7 (a∼b), and the models are labeled as Pt@MoS2(C2) and Pt@MoS2(B2). Pt is still loaded at the hexagon in the lower right corner, and the conclusion is consistent with the above discussion. The bridge site has excellent adsorption, and the formation energy is −8.09 and −7.18 eV, respectively, indicating that the heteroatom doping structure is still stable. At this point, shown in Table 4 , the effective masses of both electrons and holes are smaller than those near the doped Pt SA. This may be because after Pt loading, although the charge redistribution of atoms near the nearest hexagon is excited, it is still confined to a relatively small area. In contrast, for heteroatom doping, when it is far away from Pt, it will cause surface electron restructuring, and then improve the distribution of surface electrons due to the cooperative effect of Pt SA. Whereas, calculations show that when B is introduced, the effective masses of electrons and holes are very close, and the reaction is limited by the recombination effect after neutralization. The work function is relatively consistent, and is smaller than that of Pt@MoS2, so doping can still improve the surface electron excitation activity. In the previous discussion, we found that the HER activity is optimal near the Pt SA, confirming that the active site is near the Pt SA. Fig. 7 (c∼d) shows the HER diagram, and the Pt-H bond lengths of Pt@MoS2(C2) and Pt@MoS2(B2) are 1.556 Å and 1.584 Å, respectively, which are relatively consistent with the corresponding bond lengths in Table 3. At this point, the ΔG H* of HER is shown in Fig. 7 (e), and the ΔG H* of Pt@MoS2(C2) and Pt@MoS2(B2) are 0.158 and −1.045 eV, respectively. At this point, C doping still maintains active HER ability. Fig. 7 (f) and Tab.S2 show the numerical changes in the d-band center. The d-band center of Mo-4d orbitals in Pt@MoS2(B2) is very close to the Fermi level, which increases the binding effect on H*, resulting in a larger ΔG H*. At the same time, in H-Pt@MoS2(C2), spin polarization occurs in the Mo-3d orbitals near the Fermi level, and compared with Fig. 8 (f) and (h), it can be seen that a special orbital hybridization occurs, which can enhance the separation of charge carriers near the Fermi level [37]. Homoplastically, the changes in the Mulliken charges caused by C and B heteroatom doping (Tab.S2) are −0.37e and −0.19e, respectively, indicating that C heteroatom doping can enhance the HER process. Consequently, it can be concluded that Pt@MoS2(C2) still maintains excellent catalytic activity under the combined effects of doping, LSPR effect, and reactive oxygen species (ROS) effect [38]. It should be pointed out here that the emergence of ROS effect is due to the large surface adsorption activity and lattice distortion stress field in the defective MoS2. Such an electrode surface may greatly promote the emergence of reactive oxygen groups in the process of water adsorption and dissociation, so it causes a positive promotion effect on HER [39]. Furthermore, C doping at various sites will still have strong HER activity, making experimental regulation easier to perform. Fig. 9 illustrates the relationship between ΔG H* and pH, where the desired outcome for the catalyst's ΔG H* of HER is with in the range of (-0.2–0.2 eV). Overall, the MoS2-based SACs is more likely to undergo the HER reaction in an acidic environment. Especially, it has an advantageous boosting impact on HER in extremely acidic environments, particularly when heteroatom doping is carried out close to the Pt SA, making it a potentially valuable HER catalyst material. Further discussion on the scaling relationship between catalytic ΔG H* and characteristic properties reveals that Pt@MoS2(C) and Pt@MoS2(B) are located at the peak position(Fig. 10 (a)), exhibiting the best catalytic performance [40]. The overpotential is linearly correlated with the changes of reactants and products, reflecting the changes in the rate and thermodynamic properties of the reaction, which provides a method for guiding the design of such catalysts. Simultaneously, we discovered that the computed d-band center and the ΔG H* had a excellent linear connection. (Fig. 10 (b)). The regression model fit has an R2 of 0.96, indicating that doping can effectively modulate the catalytic ability. The dopant element and Pt SAs synergistically enhance the overall catalyst's orbital interactions, improve electronic coupling, and synergistically enhance the HER ability. 4 Conclusion This study explores the influence of adjusting the carrier surface electronic environment on the HER performance of Pt@MoS2 through theoretical calculations. The outcomes demonstrate that heteroatoms C, B, N, and P significantly modify the electronic structure of the catalyst surface and strengthen catalytic activity when doped in the six-membered ring(MoS2) of the loaded Pt SA. Among them, B and C doping have the best effect, and the ΔG H* can reach −0.004 and −0.071 eV, respectively. Further investigation of C and B doping in other positions reveals that the C-doped catalyst still maintains excellent charge transfer ability, relying on the combined effects of the LSPR effect, ROS effect, and doping effect to promote the HER process. This study additionally illustrates how C doping, which is simple to accomplish in experiments, is ubiquitous and has beneficial catalytic activity. Future research should broaden the doping element system and carefully investigate how doping affects the catalyst's surface electrical structure. This paper offers suggestions for doping-controlled catalyst coordination conditions alongside a research bases. coredata.dc:description: MoS2 has received a lot of attention as a carrier for single-atom catalysts owing to its stable layered structure and outstanding electrical transport characteristics. We developed a model that represents the Pt@MoS2 SACs in this study on anatomical coordination environment with doping elements consisting of C, B, N, and P. It was investigated how catalytic and electrical properties interact with HER activity.The outcomes shown that C, B, N, and P significantly modified the electronic structure of the catalyst surface and enhanced catalytic activity when doped into the loaded Pt single atom of MoS2. The best effects were seen with B and C doping, with free energies reaching -0.004 and -0.071 eV, respectively. The universality of the doping sites made it simpler to produce in experiments, because C doping in other positions still had fantastic catalytic activity. The project is anticipated to offer a theoretical framework for further exploration of MoS2 in the catalytic arena and the investigation of analogous structured catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of doping and modulation on hydrogen evolution reaction of Pt@MoS2 single-atom catalysts: A first-principles study
